title: Leafsnap: A Computer Vision System for Automatic Plant Species Identification

author: Neeraj Kumar, Computer Science and Engineering, Dept. of Computer Science & Engineering, University of Washington
chairman: Michal Irani, Weizmann Institute of Science
Andrea Vedaldi, Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford

segmentation: So today I'm going to present our work on Leaf Snap, a computer vision system for automatic plant species identification.

This is joint work with my advisor, Peter Belhumeur from Colombia, Argit Bishwas, David Jacobs, and Joe Allosaurus from University of Maryland and John, Chris and Ida Lopez from the Smithsonian Institution.
So let's say you're out for a walk in the park, and you come, you come.
History and you want to know what species it is?
Well, how would you do that the traditional way it has been practiced for over 1000 years is to use a field guide.
So let's do that.
Here's a field guide and we're going to open it up and we find a series of questions.
Questions like are the margins of the leaf smoother, serrated, or is the leaf simple or compound?
Now?
We don't quite understand what all of these terms mean, but we muddled through an 15 or 20 minutes later we get to an answer.
Unfortunately, it's not the right one.
And sadly, this is an all too common occurrence when trying to use a field guide.
It's a very error prone manual and time consuming process and it's extremely frustrating, especially for kids.
So, so one such kid was actually Peter's son William and after a particularly aggravating experience trying to use one, he turned to Peter and he said, hey Dad, you do stuff with computers, right?
Why don't you make this thing?
That lets you compare plants you might find with plants that you want to find.
And so finally, several several years later, William's wish has come true in the form of leaf snap.
So.
First glance Leaf Snap looks a lot like a normal field guide.
It contains a list of species with scientific and common names for each, and a variety of images.
However, unlike a book, because we have.
App, we can do things like search and sort.
So for example, if you know that you're looking at a Magnolia, you can filter down to just the magnolias and find which species it is.
And of course William really wanted was.
Thing like this visual recognition mode where you can take a photo of a leaf and I'll tell you what it is.
So how do we go about building such a thing?
Well, one idea would be to take the decision tree encoded in a book field guide and convert it to computer form.
But this is not a good idea.
And this example shows why.
These are several images of the paper Mulberry and you can see that there is a huge amount of intraclass variation.
So instead, if we had access to lots of images of leaves of the same species, we could use a more standard machine learning pipeline.
Unfortunately, because leaves do in fact grow on trees, this is easy to do.
So let's see what iPhone images look like, because that's the device we're going to be dealing with.
Here is an image of a leaf taken with an iPhone and you can see a couple of things you can see that the image is blurry.
It's not flat, but I mean the leaf is not completely flat.
If you look at another leaf, you see that the colors can be quite different and that there can be significant shadows throughout the image.
Some leaves don't even look like leaves and instead consists of thin structures like this with no Venetian patterns that we might use for recognition.
Yet other leaves have color splotches on them, or severe white balancing issues.
So, given all of these sources of variation that we're dealing with with iPhone images, how should we do our recognition?

Well, as it turns out, the shape of leaves can be quite distinctive, so here are the shapes for four different leaf species, and you can distinguish the ones on the left because they have smooth edges and the ones on the right has serrated edges.
Now this is something that you could compute by computing the curvature along the boundary of the leaf, for example.
Similarly, to distinguish the top row from the bottom row, you notice that the top row consists of leaves with five loads, and the bottom row consists of leaves with single lobes.
Now, this also you can think of a sort of curvature feature, except we're computing curvature at the very core scale along the boundary of the leaves.
And so therefore we're going to use for recognition.
It's curvatures at many different scales computed along the boundaries of segmented leaves.
OK, so.
Let's look at the first part of this segmentation.
Now for simplicity we ask the user to place the image, place a leaf on a plain colored background.
For example, a sheet of paper, and this makes the problem easier, but it's still not easy because we have to deal with all the sources of variation I just showed you and we have to do this very fast.
No one wants to wait for hours or even minutes to get the result of species leaf is.
So the first thing we do is we convert the image to the saturation value color space, which we have found to be relatively stable in the presence of color and lighting changes.
Our segmentation model is as follows.
We want to estimate pics.
Otherwise, the label for each pixel using a set of parameters.
There are two classes, the foreground and background, and the parameters are the mean color for each class and a shared covariance matrix.
We don't hardcode these parameters, but instead we estimate them from the image directly using.
Expectation maximization framework.
So here are the results after convergence for this leaf and you can see that we get a nice clustering of pixels into either leaf or background, and this is the resulting segmentation.
Let's look at some more segmentation results.
Here they are for three different leaf species of very different types, and you can see that segmentation works quite well.
But there's still some problems.
For example, the middle leaf was taken on a notebook which doesn't quite cover the field of view, and so around the boundaries.
We get some false positive segmentations.
We deal with this by running a postprocessing step that removes such false positives.
Another common problem that we've found is at least can have stems of varying lengths, so to normalize.
For this we run another.
Step which gets reduced to leave the stems entirely in all the segmentation process takes about 110th of a second.
Now, given a segmented leaf, we want to compute our features on it.
The traditional way of computing curvature is easier is using differential measures, where you place a point down, look at the two neighboring points and compute the angle between them.
However, this is not robust on discrete grids such as images of pixels due to a variety of factors such as rotation, segmentation errors, scale changes and so on.
You can often get catastrophic failure of the curvature computation, so instead we use.
Google measure yourself curvature.
These don't suffer from the existing problems and they are simple to understand and simple to implement.
What we do is we place a circle down at the point of interest and count the number of white pixels inside the circle divided by the area of the circle.
So if you're at a straight boundary point, you get a value of .5.
For convex regions you get a value less than .5.
And for concave regions you get value more than .5.
Another nice thing about these integral measures is that they have a natural built-in notion of scale.
The radius of the disk so.
Use a larger disk.
You're essentially ignoring small variations that are much smaller than the size of the disk.
And so this will form our fundamental operator.
We will use to compute our feature.
The feature itself is a histogram of curvatures taken along the boundary of the.
We compute this.
Histogram at many different scales and then concatenate the resulting histograms together to form our final feature.
OK, let's get back to the app.

So in the app the user is taking the photo an we perform recognition using the segmentation and feature extraction I just mentioned along with the very simple nearest neighbor classifier this gives us.
A set of rank results as shown here.
Now the question is which species is it?
Well to quantitatively evaluate this, we randomly fan out experiment there was also.
Which are shown here.

The first point on this graph says that the first match shown is the correct one 7072% of the time, and this point says that the correct result is within the top five matches 93% of the time, and as we go out to 10:15 twenty, we essentially are right all the time.

Now of course, this is only true if the species you photograph is within our data set, and so right now our data set consists of 185 tree species, which covers all of the trees of the Northeastern United States, and we're in process of gathering data for the rest of the United States, and then for the world.
OK, so there's a high likelihood that the first few matches are correct, but again, which one is it?
To verify this, the user can click on any of the species.
Look at a variety of high quality images of the leaf, the flower, the fruit.
The stem and even the bark of all the species.
In addition, the app provides.
Text descriptions provided by the Smithsonian Institution, which give a lot of detail information about that species.
So using all of this information.
The user can then label the image as.
In this case the Japanese Maple.
Which is then added to their call.
Action the collection shows all the trees that you've ever photographed and when you photograph them, and in addition because iPhones have GPS, you can also see.
Where you photographed all the trees?
Now the exciting thing for us is that by aggregating these labels over all our users, we can build a map.
This this is the last 1000 photographed and labeled tree species in the New York City region, and in fact we can build Maps like this throughout the world because our apps have been quite successful.
We've had nearly 1,000,000 downloads for iPhone and iPad apps since our launch, and we're getting about 40,000 users every month.
In addition, the app certainly seems to be working to some degree since we have about 100,000 active users who come back and use the app over and over again.

Now we've heard from users all over the world and everyone is very excited and very happy to use this app, and we've been quite surprised at the variety of people who are interested in something like this.
It's everyone from botanists to educators, kids, hobbyist hikers, photographers.
It's quite a varied bunch, and in fact, one thing that almost everyone comments on is how how interesting it is and how nice it is to use a system which has computer vision integrated into it.
So because and also because of this, we've had.
A high amount of press coverage, which in turn has helped us get more users.
So because of the popularity of the.
Apps there are a lot of interesting future directions for us to pursue.
I'm going to name just three of them here.
First, the Smithsonian is already using Leaf snap as part of their education and outreach programs, and since this is one of the primary missions, they're very happy that they can do this.

2nd, a lot of governments and organizations would like to track the biodiversity of flora in their local regions, and leaf snap is a way to do this over space and time in a way that is unprecedented in the amount of detail it gives you.
And 3rd one sleeve snap can classify all the known species of the world.
Bot Nets are very excited to be able to use it to help in discovering and classifying knew undiscovered species of trees.
So in closing, we just like to urge the vision community not to underestimate nitches like plants.
If you're interested in birds or dogs, or fish or cars, you should build something and people will be interested.
And lots of people will be interested.
And as long as you build something that really works out in the wild and you can make it easy to use.
So.
That I'd like to close.

I'd like to mention that our apps and data set in code will be online, at least snap.com, and I'd like to thank all our volunteers shown blue and or users, some of which are shown in this first grade classroom.
Thank you.

We based on segmentation.
We normalize the areas to be equal before processing to use the GPS data for classification as well.

Do use user logs to help retrain the classifier.
Can use like user feedback to help Re label different images?
Yes, so we're very interested in seeing what we can do with all the labels we've gathered.
Right now there's a number of things you have to be careful about because you don't know if the user labeling things correctly or not.
So we are thinking about various things we might do.
For example, having a small set of.
